author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Artie Shaw: Time Is All You’ve Got’ Review: A Lens on a Jazz Luminary
description: Brigitte Berman’s dazzling 1985 look at the self-taught virtuoso clarinetist and bandleader is showing after a restoration.
content: The documentarian Brigitte Berman has made two spectacular pictures about American jazz pioneers. The first, “Bix: ‘Ain’t None of Them Play Like Him Yet’” (1981), chronicled the life of the brilliant and tragically short-lived cornetist and composer Bix Beiderbecke. It screened in a restoration at Film Forum a couple of years back. Now, her follow-up to that movie, “Artie Shaw: Time Is All You’ve Got” (1985), is similarly restored and booked at Film Forum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Citing Misinformation, Florida Health Official Calls for Halt to Covid Vaccines
description: Federal health officials and other experts have repeatedly sought to counter erroneous comments about the vaccines by Dr. Joseph Ladapo, Florida’s surgeon general.
content: Florida’s surgeon general on Wednesday called for a halt to the use of Covid vaccines, citing widely debunked concerns that contaminants in the vaccine can permanently integrate into human DNA.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: DeSantis and Haley Will Appear in Back-to-Back Town Halls Tonight
description: The events, on CNN, will give the two candidates a prominent chance to make their case to Iowa Republicans ahead of the caucuses on Jan. 15.
content: It’s another busy day on the presidential campaign trail in Iowa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: New York City Sues Bus Companies That Brought 30,000 Migrants From Texas
description: The lawsuit accuses 17 companies of carrying out a plan by the governor of Texas to send tens of thousands of migrants to New York.
content: Mayor Eric Adams of New York on Thursday ratcheted up his feud with Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas, filing suit against 17 transportation companies that he said had carried out a plan by Mr. Abbott to send more than 30,000 migrants to New York City and make the city pay for their care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Flowers Are Evolving to Have Less Sex
description: As the number of bees and other pollinators falls, field pansies are adapting by fertilizing their own seeds, a new study found.
content: Every spring, trillions of flowers mate with the help of bees and other animals. They lure the pollinators to their flowers with flashy colors and nectar. As the animals travel from flower to flower, they take pollen with them, which can fertilize the seeds of other plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Major French Retailer Drops PepsiCo Products Over High Prices
description: Carrefour, a supermarket chain, said the maker of Pepsi, Lay’s and 7-Up was keeping its food “unacceptably” expensive despite falling inflation.
content: The economic headlines in Europe have been glowing recently: Inflation, according to official statistics, is finally coming down. But tell that to consumers still facing runaway prices when they head to the supermarket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Haley Jokes That New Hampshire Primary Will ‘Correct’ Iowa’s Result
description: Ms. Haley, campaigning in New Hampshire, quipped that “Iowa starts it. You know that you correct it.” Allies of Gov. Ron DeSantis pounced.
content: Campaigning in New Hampshire on Wednesday, former Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina said that voters there would “correct” the result of the Iowa caucuses — the night before she was scheduled to appear for events in Iowa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Judge Refuses to Send Defendant in Drug Case to Troubled Brooklyn Jail
description: A federal judge ordered that a man remain free to await sentencing rather than be sent to the Metropolitan Detention Center, citing terrible conditions there.
content: A federal judge, citing complaints of dreadful conditions, near perpetual lockdowns and grave staffing shortages in a long-troubled federal jail in Brooklyn, refused Wednesday to order a man convicted in a drug case to be sent there while awaiting sentencing in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Want to Understand 2024? Look at 1948.
description: Americans were angry with Truman because of high prices in the aftermath of World War II, even as other economic signals looked promising.
content: In the era of modern consumer confidence data, there has never been an economy quite like this recent one — with prices rising so high and unemployment staying so low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Crisis in the Red Sea, and Epstein Files Unsealed
description: Hear the news in five minutes.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Martha Diamond, Painter Who Captured New York Vistas, Dies at 79
description: Her work, at the border of representation and abstraction, cast a strong influence over younger painters but did not gain broad public recognition until late in her life.
content: Martha Diamond, a painter’s painter who captured the endlessly changing face of New York’s buildings, streets and light-filled vistas with deceptively simple expanses of color, died on Saturday after a long illness. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Day 4: Identify Your ‘Energy Vampires’ and ‘Chaotic Friends’
description: Today you’ll explore whether your relationships are uplifting or depleting.
content: This is Day 4 of the 6-Day Energy Challenge. To start at the beginning, click here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Fight Over D.E.I. in the C-suite
description: Claudine Gay’s resignation as Harvard president is adding to the wider debate in boardrooms over diversity, equity and inclusion policies.
content: Even though Claudine Gay’s resignation as president of Harvard was tied to plagiarism allegations, debate on a broader culture war’s role in the move is grabbing lots of attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Massachusetts Switches On Its First Large Offshore Wind Farm
description: Vineyard Wind is the country’s second large-scale offshore project to start producing electricity and comes at a turbulent time for the industry.
content: The first large offshore wind farm in New England has started producing electricity, a milestone for an industry that has struggled to get off the ground over the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Where Did the Snow Go?
description: “A visceral feeling of what climate change looks and feels like.”
content: Almost no one in the United States experienced a white Christmas. Ski areas in the West are closed. The Great Lakes began the year with the lowest amount of ice in at least 50 years. Midwesterners are jogging in T-shirts in the dead of winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Mike Sadler, Intrepid Desert Navigator in World War II, Dies at 103
description: Like a human GPS, he guided Britain’s first special forces across the vast Sahara for hit-and-run raids on enemy bases in the battle against Rommel’s forces.
content: Maj. Mike Sadler, a World War II navigator on the trackless Sahara of North Africa, who guided Britain’s first special forces across sand seas on daring behind-the-lines night raids that blew up enemy aircraft on the ground and troops in their billets, died on Thursday in Cambridge, England. He was 103.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: In Overnight Sweep, Police in Berkeley Clear Protesters From People’s Park
description: The University of California, Berkeley, has been trying for years, against determined opposition, to build new student housing on part of the iconic property.
content: A fraught battle to build long-sought student housing at the storied People’s Park in Berkeley, Calif., took an extraordinary turn early on Thursday when hundreds of law enforcement officers surrounded the site and removed several dozen activists and homeless campers in preparation for the construction of a wall of shipping containers around the perimeter of the park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer, Hurubie Meko and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Homicides and Shootings Fell in New York City as Felony Assaults Rose
description: Car thefts also increased amid a slight drop in crime overall in 2023, police officials said on Wednesday.
content: Overall crime fell slightly in New York City last year compared with 2022, though the number of felony assaults and car thefts remained stubbornly high, the police said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jill McCorkle Is Getting Over Her ‘Henry James Phobia’
description: Finishing “The Portrait of a Lady” leaves the author of “Old Crimes,” a new story collection, “a little more confident.” Meanwhile, Rod Serling has a place on her shelves.
content: What books are on your night stand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Mitch Smith
title: Trump Ballot Challenges Advance, Varying Widely in Strategy and Sophistication
description: Donald J. Trump’s eligibility for the presidential ballot has been challenged in more than 30 states, but only a handful of those cases have gained traction so far.
content: John Anthony Castro, a 40-year-old Texan, long-shot Republican presidential candidate and the most prolific challenger of Donald J. Trump’s eligibility to be president, has gone to court in at least 27 states trying to remove the former president from the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should Trump Be Removed From the Ballot?
description: Readers react to recent articles about the 14th Amendment. Also: Reflections on Claudine Gay’s resignation as the president of Harvard.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost and Maya Tekeli
title: Denmark’s Next Queen Is a Progressive, Common-Born Former Australian
description: “I don’t recall wishing that one day I would be a princess,” Princess Mary told reporters. “I wanted to be a veterinarian.”
content: It was a classic Australian love story, set in a Sydney pub: Girl meets boy. Girl marries boy. Girl lives happily ever after.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 8, 2024
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump Wants Prosecutors Held in Contempt in Federal Election Case
description: The former president’s lawyers sought to have Jack Smith and two deputies explain why they should not be held in contempt of court for taking new steps in the case after it was put on hold.
content: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump said on Thursday that they want the special counsel, Jack Smith, and two of his top deputies to be held in contempt of court and sanctioned for violating a judge’s order that effectively froze the criminal case accusing Mr. Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin, Victor Mather and Leah McBride Mensching
title: Sixth Grader Killed and 5 Others Injured in Iowa School Shooting
description: Four other students and an administrator were injured in the shooting at an Iowa school. The gunman, identified as a 17-year-old student, died from a self-inflicted gunshot, the authorities said.
content: A gunman killed a sixth-grade student and injured five other people at a high school in Perry, Iowa, early Thursday morning just as students were arriving back to school after their winter break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Tech Executive Sold Banned Chinese Products to State Agencies, U.S. Says
description: The owner of a technology company persuaded New Jersey public safety officials to spend at least $35 million on security equipment, a federal complaint says.
content: The owner of a technology company duped public safety and law enforcement agencies in New Jersey into spending at least $35 million, including $15 million in Covid-19 relief and other federal funding, on banned Chinese surveillance and security equipment, according to a complaint unveiled this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: G.O.P. Senate Group Files Brief in Support of Trump’s Colorado Ballot Appeal
description: The National Republican Senatorial Committee argued in an amicus brief that the Colorado Supreme Court overstepped in disqualifying former President Donald J. Trump from the primary ballot.
content: The top Republican Senate campaign group filed a brief on Wednesday with the United States Supreme Court in support of Donald J. Trump’s appeal of a Colorado ruling blocking him from the state’s presidential ballot. It is the latest sign of the rallying effect that the former president’s legal woes are having on his party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: How a Drag Queen Event That Never Happened Forced a Library to Shut Down
description: In April, Drag Queen Story Hour was announced. Protests erupted, and by September, the library was forced to close. It still hasn’t reopened.
content: Lake Luzerne, in upstate New York, is a small mountain town of weathered clapboard houses, with a spired church on Main Street and a public library that offered internet access, a food pantry and twice-weekly story hours for children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Fresh Spring Rolls, Pan-Seared Chicken With Harissa, and Salt and Vinegar Kale Chips
description: Fast and fun recipes for any resolution.
content: Tanya Sichynsky — a senior staff editor you might know from The Veggie — has written a friendly “start here” guide for common cooking resolutions. It’s worth a read, especially for this encouraging suggestion: “Try to become just a little bit better at something, rather than change your habits wholesale.” If one of your resolutions is to eat less red meat, we have plenty of inspiring recipes for you, including this new one by Ali Slagle for fresh spring rolls. They’re light yet filling, especially if eaten with a limey, chile-spiked peanut sauce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Vatican Defends Gay Blessings, but Offers Critics Some Leeway
description: The clarification on a declaration issued in December seemed designed to soothe critics while also showing that this is the way forward.
content: In the weeks since Pope Francis approved a rule allowing the blessing of same-sex couples, some bishops in conservative corners of the church, such as Africa, have said they wouldn’t allow priests to perform the practice, which they believe contradicts church doctrine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Case for Disqualifying Trump Is Strong
description: Worrying about “consequences” is not a legal argument.
content: It’s been just over two weeks since the Colorado Supreme Court ruled that Section 3 of the 14th Amendment disqualifies Donald Trump from holding the office of president of the United States. It stayed the effect of that ruling until this week. Pending further action from the Supreme Court of the United States — which Trump asked on Wednesday to overturn the ruling — the former president is off the Republican primary ballot in Colorado.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Curtis, Larissa Anderson and Daniel Ramirez
title: Oprah Winfrey and Gayle King’s Iconic Friendship
description: Stories and insights from their enduring connection.
content: Oprah Winfrey and Gayle King talk with Jancee Dunn, a Well columnist at The New York Times, about what’s kept their friendship strong for close to 50 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Friedman
title: 8 Fitness Myths That Drive Experts Crazy
description: Running is bad for your knees. The heavier the weight the better. Ice baths. And more.
content: When done right, exercise can be a veritable miracle drug. But follow the wrong advice and you can easily set yourself up for injury. Take the sit-up: Once considered the gold standard of core exercises, we now know that it can make low-back pain worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Christie Says in a New Ad That He Was Wrong to Support Trump in 2016
description: “Now, we’re confronted with the very same choice again,” former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said in the ad, rejecting calls to end his campaign in order to narrow the anti-Trump field.
content: Former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said in a new ad released Thursday that he had been wrong to endorse Donald J. Trump in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Trump Meets With Teamsters President as Union Weighs 2024 Endorsement
description: The Teamsters union has yet to endorse a presidential candidate, even as President Biden has called himself the most pro-union president in history.
content: Sean M. O’Brien, the general president of the Teamsters union, sat down with former President Donald J. Trump on Wednesday at Mr. Trump’s seaside mansion, Mar-a-Lago, in Palm Beach, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Holly Jackson’s Maximization of Google Maps
description: In her “A Good Girl’s Guide to Murder” series and “Five Survive,” this British author makes herself at home on the East Coast.
content: How does a London-based novelist concoct a convincing story set in the United States? Some might splurge for a temporary relocation in the name of research, but Holly Jackson opts for a virtual visit via Google Maps. Navigating from street views to real estate listings — and even, eventually, to electoral records — she’ll piece together a universe for her characters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Happy Puppies and Silly Geese: Pushing the Limits of A.I. Absurdity
description: A recent update to ChatGPT made it easier to create images. It wasn’t long before some began pushing the chatbot to its limits.
content: What is the happiest dog you can imagine? Is it beaming with joy on a celestial plane or frolicking in a field of psychedelic flora?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl
title: Told Ya So: The Prescient Posters of the Environmental Movement
description: Graphic artists have been helping call attention to climate change for decades, and a new exhibition charts the evolution of their pleas.
content: Last year was the warmest in recorded history. The graphic artists of the environmental movement tried to warn us. Their posters aimed to scare people straight with pictures of ecological ruin, or glorified nature, clean air and water, sunshine and verdure. Some offered earworm-y slogans and haunting visuals. Whatever their approach — bright, witty, somber, blunt, even sexy — they sought an image, a phrase, that could change enough minds to literally save the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: A Trophy in Ruins: Evidence Grows That Russia Controls Marinka
description: Ukraine said it was defending territory behind the eastern frontline town. Its capture would be Russia’s most significant territorial advance in Ukraine in more than six months.
content: The Ukrainian military said on Thursday that its troops were fighting “in the vicinities” of a village behind the eastern frontline town of Marinka, a strong indication that Kyiv’s forces have lost control of the town, more than a week after Moscow claimed to have seized it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: These New Laws Just Took Effect in California
description: Toy stores must have gender-neutral sections, employers must provide more sick days and more.
content: New year, new rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Connected to the Spine
description: Chase Dittrich and Christina Iverson spell things out for us.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A.I. Questions, Answered
description: We ask Times technology reporters to make artificial intelligence more comprehensible.
content: I want to make a confession: I don’t understand a lot of the hype around artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Why London’s Tube Is Shutting Down Next Week
description: Large strikes by workers on the London Underground are expected to cripple the capital’s transportation network for several days.
content: Millions of London commuters are bracing for public transit chaos next week, as strikes are expected to shut down the city’s underground Tube system for several days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Ambulance Workers in Texas Are Reeling Under the Border Surge
description: Washington politicians are traveling to Eagle Pass, Texas, to highlight the politics of the border crisis. For local officials, the real cost is measured in lives and money.
content: Through the long, busy months of autumn, the calls kept coming in: Mothers losing grip of their children while trying to cross the treacherous waters of the Rio Grande. Pregnant women getting caught in barbed wire. Bodies washing up on shore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Night Swim’ Review: Hold Your Breath, Forever
description: The backyard pool is a symbol of love and of terror in this uneven but scary horror film.
content: Hollywood horror often attempts to work out collective anxiety about the suburbs, that place full of pleasant-looking houses creaking with ghosts and terrors. Suburban life is, admittedly, fundamentally strange, with neighborhoods full of atomized worlds and natural features turned into individual, highly-controlled assets. A forest becomes manicured bushes. A lake becomes a pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and the Bronx
description: This week’s properties are in East Harlem, the West Village and Mott Haven.
content: A one-bedroom, one-bath, 600-square-foot apartment with an open floor plan, built-ins in the bedroom, frosted-glass barn doors, central air-conditioning and a balcony, on the ninth floor of a 12-story doorman building with a garden, gym, roof deck, residents’ lounge, children’s play area, bike room, shared laundry and a live-in super. Jenny Delaney, Bond New York, 917-208-9185; bondnewyork.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Anderson
title: Winter Storm Traps Hundreds of Motorists Overnight in Sweden
description: Truck drivers and other motorists were locked in blankets of snow on a major roadway overnight after nearly 10 inches of snow fell within 24 hours.
content: Thick blankets of snow and strong winds trapped hundreds of motorists in their vehicles overnight on Wednesday on a major roadway in southern Sweden, forcing emergency workers to call for help from the Swedish military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: A Good Coat Is Hard to Find
description: Paynter Jacket Co., a small label in London, has built a loyal following thanks to its limited-edition chore coats.
content: Fi Cotter Craig, a television producer in Britain, was scrolling through Instagram one day when she was struck by a photo. “I saw my friend wearing a jacket that I actually thought I would kill her for,” Ms. Cotter Craig said. “Rather than kill her, I rang her up and said, ‘Where did you get that jacket?’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Trump Received Millions From Foreign Governments as President, Report Finds
description: House Democrats released evidence that he took in at least $7.8 million from foreign entities while in office, engaging in the kind of conduct the G.O.P. is grasping to pin on President Biden.
content: Donald J. Trump’s businesses received at least $7.8 million from 20 foreign governments during his presidency, according to new documents released by House Democrats on Thursday that show how much he received from overseas transactions while he was in the White House, most of it from China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and William K. Rashbaum
title: As the Art World Watches, an Oligarch Takes an Auction House to Court
description: At trial next week, Dmitry Rybolovlev is set to accuse Sotheby’s of helping an art dealer trick him into wildly overspending for works, a claim the company disputes.
content: In 2013, when Dmitry Rybolovlev, a Russian oligarch, was in the midst of buying $2 billion worth of art, one of the many works he purchased was “Tête,” a sculpture by Modigliani, for $83 million. That, he says, was the price Yves Bouvier, a man helping to handle the transaction, told him the seller would need to part with such a masterpiece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: How Do You Feel About High School?
description: Scroll through some work by the winning students and educators who participated in our “What High School Is Like in 2023” multimedia challenge. Then tell us how well the collection captures your experiences.
content: Please note: We invite teenagers and adults to reflect on the winning student and teacher work from our “What High School Is Like in 2023” challenge by posting comments here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin and Eric Schmitt
title: Iraq Condemns U.S. After Drone Strike in Baghdad
description: The attack, acknowledged by the Pentagon, killed a senior militant leader of an Iran-allied group with ties to the Iraqi government’s security apparatus.
content: A U.S. Special Operations drone strike in Baghdad on Thursday killed a senior figure in an Iran-linked militant group that is part of Iraq’s security apparatus, drawing sharp criticism from the Iraqi government, as well as allied groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Paxlovid Cuts Covid Death Risk. But Those Who Need It Are Not Taking It.
description: With Covid deaths rising to about 1,500 per week, researchers question why Paxlovid use has remained low among high-risk patients.
content: As Covid rises again, killing about 1,500 Americans each week, medical researchers are trying to understand why so few people are taking Paxlovid, a medicine that is stunningly effective in preventing severe illness and death from the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in January
description: This week we introduce a new format for Galleries with one critic at the helm, searching out new artists and some of the most notable exhibitions. Here, Roberta Smith covers the New York debut of Sagarika Sundaram along with shows by Robert Ryman, Blair Saxon-Hill and Clintel Steed.
content: This week we introduce a new format for Galleries with one critic at the helm, searching out new artists and some of the most notable exhibitions. Here, Roberta Smith covers the New York debut of Sagarika Sundaram along with shows by Robert Ryman, Blair Saxon-Hill and Clintel Steed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Kim Jong-un’s Daughter Is His Likely Successor, South Korea Says
description: Kim Ju-ae has long accompanied her dictator father to important state events, like long-range missile tests and military parades.
content: The young daughter of North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, who has frequently accompanied her father at public events, including long-range missile tests, is Mr. Kim’s most likely successor should he die, the South Korean intelligence agency told lawmakers on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: The N.Y.P.D. Dance Team Walks the Beat and Feels It Too
description: This squad is finding its niche in a department where most clubs are dedicated to traditionally macho pastimes.
content: Officer Lauren Pagán looked at the line of dancers in the overheated cafeteria at a Queens high school on a recent Monday night and frowned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: New Year, Very Old Restaurants
description: Start 2024 with the classics: prime rib hash at Keens, a grilled Muenster on black bread with sautéed mushrooms at the Old Town and more.
content: Happy new year. January is usually a month of fresh starts and new chapters. But to tell you the truth, I’m not ready to face the future yet. I don’t know if it’s the short afternoons, the feeble sunshine, the chafing wind or just a creeping dread of what might be down the road. But after New Year’s Day, when other people are ordering mocktails and grinding away on the Peloton, I often find myself in some old restaurant or other, holding a beer and dwelling on the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: The 7 Keys to Longevity
description: Ignore the hyperbaric chambers and infrared light: These are the evidence-backed secrets to aging well.
content: Humans have searched for the secret to immortality for thousands of years. For some people today, that quest includes things like sleeping in a hyperbaric chamber, experimenting with cryotherapy or blasting oneself with infrared light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Rubsam
title: The Newest ‘Godzilla’ Film Is Stranger Than Fiction
description: Effects artists annihilate cities in movies all the time. Tokyo really was destroyed, a reality the best Godzilla stories have always taken seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘He Went That Way’ Review: On the Road With a Serial Killer
description: In this thriller, the Australian actor Jacob Elordi tries on the tics of noteworthy American performers, from James Dean to Matt Dillon.
content: Apparently, some time in 1964, a professional ice skater and animal trainer named Dave Pitts, on the road with his chimp Spanky, picked up a young hitchhiker who was in the middle of a killing spree. The story of Pitts’s encounter with Larry Lee Ranes, whose brother also became a serial killer, was fictionalized in Conrad Hilberry’s book “Luke Karamazov.” That book is the source of “He Went That Way,” the picturesque feature directing debut of the cinematographer Jeff Darling, who died in a surfing accident in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walker Mimms
title: Luna Luna: A Fantasy That Comes With a Price Tag
description: A blockbuster restaging of an “art amusement park” from 1987 aims to recover a lost element in art — fun. But in our age of hype and commerce, was it doomed to fall short?
content: What happened to fun? In the clinical white of the gallery, art can be forbidding, aggrieved, elite, academic. Shouldn’t it also, sometimes, be joyous?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: How to Claim a Share of Verizon’s $100 Million Proposed Settlement
description: Verizon customers that were charged administrative fees are eligible to apply, though payments are likely to be small and rise to $100 at most.
content: Some Verizon customers may be entitled to claim part of a $100 million proposed settlement that the wireless carrier agreed to pay to resolve a class-action lawsuit, according to a claims website set up by a settlement administrator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Benjamin Weiser
title: Unsealed Documents Shed Light on Epstein’s Misdeeds, and Little Else
description: The court documents include unredacted names of the disgraced financier and sex-offender’s associates, most of which had been widely publicized already.
content: Hundreds of pages of previously sealed court documents related to Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier and registered sex offender, were made public Wednesday — but as most legal experts familiar with the sordid affair had surmised, there was no smoking gun list of famous men who had sought to have sex with young women and teen girls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Marks
title: Look What We Made Taylor Swift Do
description: Whether she is conscious of it or not, Ms. Swift signals to queer people — in our language — that she has some affinity for queer identity.
content: In 2006, the year Taylor Swift released her first single, a closeted country singer named Chely Wright, then 35, held a 9-millimeter pistol to her mouth. Queer identity was still taboo enough in mainstream America that speaking about her love for another woman would have spelled the end of a country music career. But in suppressing her identity, Ms. Wright had risked her life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Persecution of Harvard’s Claudine Gay
description: As Black women have raised their profiles, they’ve also raised some right-wing hackles.
content: Claudine Gay, the president of Harvard who announced her resignation on Tuesday after her problematic congressional testimony about antisemitism and mounting questions about missing citations and quotation marks in her published work, was, in part, pushed out by political forces beyond academia and hostile to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: 30 Shows to Watch This Winter
description: This season promises a deluge of big stars (Nicole Kidman, Kate Winslet), intriguing adaptations (“Avatar: The Last Airbender”), long-awaited returns (“True Detective”) and final goodbyes (“Curb Your Enthusiasm”).
content: Is it a delayed effect of the writers’ and actors’ strikes? The Year of the Dragon? Climate change? Whatever the reason, a paper-thin fall season on television screens (definitely a result of the strikes) is being followed by a deluge of attention-grabbing shows this winter. A-list stars (Jodie Foster, Nicole Kidman, Kate Winslet), intriguing adaptations and reboots (“3 Body Problem,” “Avatar: The Last Airbender”), long-awaited returns (welcome back, “True Detective”) and final goodbyes (so long, “Curb Your Enthusiasm”) abound. Throw in all the delayed broadcast-network premieres — your various “Chicago,” “FBI,” “NCIS” and “Law and Order” series, among others — and it promises to be exhausting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Judge in Las Vegas Attacked By Man Who Was Denied Probation
description: In a scene captured on video, Deobra Redden, 30, jumped over a courtroom bench onto Judge Mary Kay Holthus as he was about to be sentenced, court officials said.
content: A man who had been denied probation attacked a judge during his sentencing in a Nevada courtroom on Wednesday in a violent episode that was captured on video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Miriam Jordan
title: Biden Faces Pressure on Immigration, and Not Just From Republicans
description: Mayors and governors from President Biden’s own party are looking for help with overflowing migrant encampments, packed shelters and busted budgets.
content: President Biden is under growing pressure to curb record numbers of migrants crossing into the United States — not just from the usual Republican critics, but also from Democratic mayors and governors in cities thousands of miles from the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Mooj Zadie, Clare Toeniskoetter, John Ketchum, Diane Wong and Alyssa Moxley
title: Why Are So Many More Pedestrians Dying in the U.S.?
description: Other rich nations have surpassed America in protecting pedestrians, cyclists and motorists.
content: A puzzling new pattern has taken hold on American roads: pedestrian traffic deaths, which had been on the decline for years, have skyrocketed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: A U.S. Strike Killed an Iran-allied Militant Leader
description: Also, Biden faces immigration pressure from Democrats. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: A U.S. drone strike in Baghdad today killed the leader of a militant group linked to Iran that is part of Iraq’s security apparatus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: For Six Months, Bringing Dark Stories to Light
description: Debra Kamin spoke with current and former agents at eXp Realty, a real estate brokerage, where several women said they had been victims of drugging and sexual assault.
content: Last spring, Debra Kamin, who covers real estate for The New York Times, was reading an online trade publication when an article caught her attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Mayhem!’ Review: Just When You Think You’re Out
description: A former convict struggles to go straight in this ultraviolent revenge thriller.
content: No one in the mood for subtlety or nuance is likely to be beckoned by “Mayhem!,” a slugfest that cleaves to its title with punishing fidelity. A mood board of mashing, slashing, snapping and splintering, this feature, directed by Xavier Gens, is revenge-movie cliché ground down to the studs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
title: Canada’s Logging Industry Devours Forests Crucial to Fighting Climate Change
description: A study finds that logging has inflicted severe damage to the vast boreal forests in Ontario and Quebec, two of the country’s main commercial logging regions.
content: Canada has long promoted itself globally as a model for protecting one of the country’s most vital natural resources: the world’s largest swath of boreal forest, which is crucial to fighting climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: The Grim Heartbeat Propelling ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’
description: In a short but fast-moving sequence built around a children’s primer, Martin Scorsese lays out all the themes of this terrible true-crime tale.
content: Early in Martin Scorsese’s “Killers of the Flower Moon,” an Osage woman named Mollie gives her gravely unsuitable white suitor, Ernest, a Stetson. It’s a large off-white hat with a bound-edge brim and a wide ribbon around the band. It’s a gift but it feels more like a benediction, and anyone who’s ever watched an old western film (or “Star Wars”) will recognize the symbolism of her largess. Mollie is telling Ernest that she sees him as a good guy, even if the movie has already violently upended the familiar dualism of the white hat vs. black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Jeff Zucker’s Latest Bet: Prestige TV
description: The former CNN president will return to Hollywood by investing in the studio behind streaming hits like “The Morning Show” on Apple TV+.
content: Jeff Zucker is returning to the world of morning television. Sort of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What High School Is Like in 2023: The Winners of Our Multimedia Challenge
description: Via essays, poems, videos, photos, a graph, a GIF and a diorama, 25 students and teachers across the globe reflect on their lives in school.
content: Last fall, as The Learning Network celebrated 25 years of helping people teach and learn with the news, it seemed to us that education issues were making more headlines than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: New Images of Jupiter’s Moon Io Capture Infernal Volcanic Landscape
description: Juno, a NASA mission designed to study Jupiter’s origins, sent back new views of the most eruptive world in the solar system.
content: A NASA spacecraft swooped past Io, one of Jupiter’s largest moons and the most volcanically active world in our solar system. The spacecraft, the Juno orbiter, made its closest flyby yet of Io’s turbulent landscape, and sent back snapshots speckled with sharp cliffs, edgy mountain peaks, lakes of pooled lava and even a volcanic plume.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Get Ready for a Bumpy Ride
description: 2024 will be a year like no other
content: Welcome to our first Trump on Trial newsletter of 2024, a year that’s almost certain to put American democracy to the test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Seife
title: The Problems Only Start With Plagiarism
description: Academics have got to do a much better job of keeping it out of the ivory tower.
content: Plagiarism is perhaps the mildest academic sin, as well as the easiest to detect. There are innumerable cases of more serious forms of misconduct — such as the falsification and fabrication of data — that have stained the reputations of universities all over the world. If academia really wants to tackle the problem, it’s got to rethink the way it judges and rewards research — and tell good from bad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Galentine’s Day
description: How early is too early to send out save-the-dates for a get together for the gals?
content: Louis writes: My partner, Robin, enjoys hosting themed get-togethers with friends and goes all out with invitations, menus and décor. Galentine’s Day (the Valentine’s Day celebration for gal pals only) is her annual highlight, and she looks forward to it for months. This year, she wanted to send out save-the-dates in October. I said this was too early for most people. Who’s right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Year of the Vegetable
description: In for 2024: meatless meals, project cooking, luxurious breakfasts and energizing snacks.
content: Optimism abounds this time of year, the temporal fresh start a necessary reminder of our own potential for improvement, for clarity, for fulfillment. Last week, I encouraged readers to share their resolutions for the new year. I was moved by their buoyancy, particularly this note, from Suzanne:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Rage Against the Machine Says (Again) That It Will Stop Touring
description: A staple of 1990s rock music, Rage has disbanded before, including when its frontman quit in 2000. His recent leg injury forced the band to cancel its latest tour.
content: The rock band Rage Against the Machine is done touring and playing live shows, its drummer said in a social media post on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: U.S. Awards Chip Supplier $162 Million to Bolster Critical Industries
description: The Biden administration said its second grant under a new program would help Microchip Technology expand its facilities in Oregon and Colorado.
content: The Biden administration on Thursday announced plans to provide $162 million in federal grants to Microchip Technology, an Arizona-based semiconductor company that supplies the automotive, defense and other industries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Memory’ Review: A Trauma Plot
description: In this contrived movie, Peter Sarsgaard stars as a man with dementia, and Jessica Chastain plays a caretaker with buried family secrets.
content: In “Memory,” a woman haunted by her past meets a man who’s scarcely holding onto his. That’s the setup in the writer-director Michel Franco’s contrived drama with Jessica Chastain and Peter Sarsgaard, whose work in this artsified slab of exploitation cinema is strong enough that you wish their characters would run off to an entirely different movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Assessing Republicans’ Claims About Immigration During Border Visit
description: The visit to Texas reflects the extent to which immigration has become one of President Biden’s biggest political vulnerabilities, particularly as the 2024 election nears.
content: More than 60 House Republicans traveled to the southern border in Texas on Wednesday, seeking to pressure the Biden administration to enact stricter immigration policies as a record number of migrants enter the United States. They gathered near the Rio Grande in Eagle Pass, a town of fewer than 30,000 that has become a popular crossing point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: 10 Standout Marriage Proposals (Spoiler: They All Said Yes)
description: Here are some of the sweetest, funniest and most heartwarming ways that couples who wed in 2023 asked, “Will you marry me?”
content: In 2023, the weddings industry made a comeback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Good Grief’ Review: Somehow, Life Goes On
description: In his feature directorial debut, Daniel Levy applies a light but wise hand to a man navigating life after loss.
content: Romantic comedies are powered by farcical set pieces like missed connections, mistaken identities and mix-ups that lead to happy-ending fantasies. (They’re all modeled on Shakespeare, in the end.) Those sorts of moments do abound in “Good Grief,” which features pretty urbanites in pretty places learning lessons about friendship, life and love, just like a rom-com would. But to the immense credit of the movie’s writer, director and star Daniel Levy (of “Schitt’s Creek”), this is a very different kind of movie — and a much better one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: June Jackson Christmas, Pioneering Psychiatrist, Dies at 99
description: Dr. Christmas overcame race and gender barriers to run New York’s mental health agency under three mayors in the 1970s.
content: June Jackson Christmas, a psychiatrist who broke barriers as a Black woman by heading New York City’s Department of Mental Health and Retardation Services under three mayors, died on Sunday in the Bronx. She was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Listen to Oprah Winfrey and Gayle King Discuss Their Friendship
description: Best friends, Winfrey and King talk about their enduring, enlivening relationship.
content: When I picture the perfect friendship, I think of what Oprah Winfrey and Gayle King have. For around 47 years, through life and career changes, they have publicly cheered each other on with enthusiasm and love. What’s their secret to maintaining a friendship so strong for so long? I wanted to know, so I called them to chat about their near half-century together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Thursday Briefing
description: A deadly blast in Iran.
content: Two explosions at a memorial for Iran’s former top general, Qassim Suleimani, killed at least 103 people and wounded an additional 211, according to Iranian officials, sowing fear in a country where domestic unrest and the prospect of a spiraling regional war have left many on edge. The attack came at a time of heightened anxiety in Iran and across the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: How Trump Has Used Fear and Favor to Win Republican Endorsements
description: The former president keeps careful watch over his endorsements from elected Republicans, aided by a disciplined and methodical behind-the-scenes operation.
content: On his last day as president on Jan. 20, 2021, Donald J. Trump stood in a snapping wind and waved goodbye to relatives and supporters before he took his final flight on Air Force One back to Mar-a-Lago. No elected Republican of any stature showed up at Joint Base Andrews for the bleak farewell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Reacher’: Women Want What He’s Got, and Not Just the Beefcake
description: The hit Amazon series about a bone-crushing crime fighter isn’t only Dad TV. Women dream of having the character’s freedom and abilities, too.
content: You may have felt the tremor: A jacked-up beast of a guy has wandered into TV Land, and his name is Reacher. Season 1 of the Amazon series that bears his name was a monster hit when it dropped in early 2022, and Season 2, which concludes on Jan. 19, appears to be even bigger, becoming Prime Video’s No. 1 title globally on its debut weekend. And the series is crushing it critically the way Reacher crushes a villain’s skull. As of early January, the new season had a 100 percent rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an 84 percent audience score — when do critics ever rate a brawny action show higher than the audience?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: A Skeptic of the G.O.P.’s Hard Immigration Line Becomes Its Champion
description: Representative Tony Gonzales, who represents a Texas border district, drew a censure and primary opponents for defying his fellow Republicans on immigration. Now he has swung into line.
content: When Speaker Mike Johnson and scores of House Republicans converged in Eagle Pass, Texas, on Wednesday to call for a crackdown on migrants at the border, they had a somewhat unlikely host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: 2023: The Year You Didn’t Buy a House
description: Just 16 percent of homes listed in 2023 were affordable for the typical American household.
content: The year ended disappointingly for many American home buyers — fewer than 16 percent of homes for sale in 2023 were affordable to local median earners, according to a study by Redfin. That’s the lowest rate since at least 2013, the year Redfin began tracking prices, when 50 percent of homes were affordable to local median earners. In 2019, before the pandemic, 40 percent of listed homes were affordable. In 2022, only 21 percent were.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: He Ran the Uffizi. Can He Run Florence?
description: The museum’s former director, Eike Schmidt, is toying — somewhat mischievously — with entering the race to become Florence’s mayor.
content: Will he? Or won’t he?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: The Claudine Gay Debacle Was Never About Merit
description: Merit, itself, cannot be defined. That is why the concept is so useful for slippery slopes.
content: Claudine Gay’s resignation this week as Harvard University’s president marks the end of a shameful chapter for the institution. The debacle’s architects promise to make America’s elite institutions great again. They say they pushed out Dr. Gay and, nearly a month ago, the University of Pennsylvania’s president as a warning to the nation’s cultural institutions. How they will continue to wield their influence and if they will succeed depends on how willing we all are to keep buying age-old ideas about merit from power-hungry peddlers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paige McClanahan
title: In Europe, Trains Are Full, and More Are on the Way
description: Amid concerns about climate change, demand for rail service is strong, and both governments and private investors are trying to keep up. Even Eurostar may see competition on its London-Paris route.
content: Paris to Venice. Barcelona to Amsterdam. Brussels to Bratislava, Slovakia. European cities could see a flurry of new rail connections in the next few years, as governments and private investors respond to climate concerns and strive to keep up with strong demand for cross-border passenger rail traffic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Kentucky Clerk Who Denied Same-Sex Marriage Licenses Must Pay $260,000 in Legal Fees
description: Kim Davis, the former county clerk who refused to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, must pay a couple’s legal fees and expenses, a judge ruled. A jury previously ordered her to pay the couple $100,000 in damages.
content: Kim Davis, the former county clerk in Kentucky who said she refused to issue same-sex marriage licenses in 2015 because of her religious beliefs, must pay more than $260,000 in expenses and attorney fees to a couple whom she denied a license, a judge has ruled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: For Harvard’s First Black President, Race Became the Unavoidable Issue
description: Claudine Gay celebrated her history making appointment. But after she resigned, she spoke very differently about her experience.
content: In her late September inauguration, Claudine Gay looked out at a packed audience and spoke of her pride in making history as the first Black president of Harvard in its 387 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Joseph Goldstein
title: New York Could Become First State to Offer Paid Leave for Prenatal Care
description: The plan is among several the governor is proposing to address what leaders have called a maternal health crisis in New York.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul on Thursday proposed a series of initiatives to address maternal and infant death in New York, including one that would make the state the first to provide paid leave for prenatal care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Glynis Johns, Tony Winner for ‘A Little Night Music,’ Dies at 100
description: In a trans-Atlantic career that endured for more than 60 years, she was also known for her role in the hit 1965 Disney movie “Mary Poppins.”
content: Glynis Johns, the British actress who in a trans-Atlantic career that endured for more than 60 years won a Tony Award for her role in “A Little Night Music,” giving husky, emotion-rich voice to the show’s most memorable number, “Send In the Clowns,” and played an exuberant Edwardian suffragist in the Disney movie classic “Mary Poppins,” died on Thursday in Los Angeles. She was 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Alicia Napierkowski
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut.
description: This week’s properties are three-bedroom homes in Merrick, N.Y., and Redding Conn.
content: A three-bedroom, two-bath house built around 1938, with wood flooring, an open layout with dining and living areas, a kitchen with an island and a pantry, a family room with a wood-burning fireplace, a partially finished basement, a rear deck and a detached one-car garage, on a 52-by-102-foot lot. Seth Pitlake, Douglas Elliman Real Estate, 516-521-7976; elliman.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: One Indelible Scene: A Lovingly Prepared Meal in ‘The Taste of Things’
description: In a kitchen pas de deux, two cooks turn a feast into a meditation on time, longing and the seasons.
content: How a movie announces itself to you is everything, and “The Taste of Things” begins in a kitchen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Caitlin O'Keefe
title: Is the 2024 Election Already Heading to the Supreme Court?
description: Before Republican primary voters head to the polls, a thorny legal question has emerged over whether Donald Trump is eligible to be on the ballot.
content: It’s the start of the actual election year — and a new chapter in the campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Who Will Investigate One of Georgia’s Most Ambitious Politicians in the Trump Case?
description: The investigation of Lt. Gov. Burt Jones was delayed after a judge blocked the Fulton County district attorney from conducting it. Nobody has been tapped to take over.
content: Since the indictment of former President Donald J. Trump and 18 of his allies last summer on election interference charges in Georgia, a delicate question has gone unanswered: Would criminal charges also be coming for Lt. Gov. Burt Jones, a longtime Trump supporter and one of the most ambitious politicians in the Southern swing state?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Society of the Snow’ Review: The Stranded and the Faithful
description: Another movie tackles the story of the Uruguayan rugby players who survived a plane crash and turned to cannibalism.
content: Filmmakers love survival stories, but there are aspects of the so-called “miracle in the Andes” that pose special difficulties for any movie, not least because, a half-century on, the most notorious turn that events took will be well known to most viewers going in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Israelis Question Army’s Rules of Engagement After Hostages Slain
description: Israel’s military said that soldiers who shot hostages, while they waved a white flag, violated its rules of engagement. Human rights activists say the rules are good, but enforcement is lax.
content: The news that three Israeli hostages were mistakenly shot and killed last month in Gaza by soldiers meant to save them outraged many in Israel, who have since demanded answers about how the army conducts itself on the battlefield and safeguards civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Anthony Dias Blue, Whose Writing Elevated California Wines, Dies at 82
description: A longtime editor at Bon Appétit and a radio personality, he helped millions gain a new appreciation for the American wineries he loved.
content: Anthony Dias Blue, a longtime wine writer and radio personality whose love for California whites and reds helped elevate the reputation of American vintners, died on Dec. 25 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger
title: White House Says North Korea Providing Russia With Ballistic Missiles
description: Russia has rebuilt its own domestic supply of cruise missiles, but to keep up with the intensity of the barrage against Ukraine, it has been turning to North Korea and Iran.
content: The White House accused North Korea on Thursday of providing Russia with ballistic missiles that Moscow has begun to fire on targets in Ukraine, and said that in return the North was seeking a range of Russian military technologies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis PAC Makes Donations to Iowa Lawmakers Who Endorsed Him
description: Ron DeSantis has aggressively sought the endorsements of influential Iowans.
content: A political action committee controlled by Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida donated tens of thousands of dollars to Iowa legislators who have endorsed his candidacy for president, according to state campaign finance records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius, Robin Shulman Agüeros and Ana Ley
title: Subway Trains Collide in Manhattan, Causing Derailment, M.T.A. Says
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said that 24 people were injured in the collision near 96th Street. Their injuries were not serious, officials said.
content: A subway train carrying about 300 people collided with an out-of-service train near West 96th Street in Manhattan on Thursday, causing the trains to derail, Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Are You Optimistic About the State of the World?
description: A New York Times columnist argues that despite many tragic events, 2023 may have been the best year in the history of humanity. Do you agree?
content: Overall, do you think the world is becoming a better place to live? Or do dire events like wars in Ukraine and Gaza or the growing climate crisis make you worried about the fate of humanity?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitie Kelly
title: A Train Trip Through Malaysia, With Stops for Snorkeling and Wildlife Safaris
description: Plus: celestial jewelry, a new restaurant in the Himalayas and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: When I wake up, I wash my face with Relevant Complete Cleansing Serum, which is part of the skin-care line I founded in 2022. I love it because it’s hydrating and doesn’t strip your skin. Three times a week I exfoliate with The Things We Do Gly Glow Scrub. I follow up with the Relevant Beam + Glow Eye Serum, which I use all around my eyes but also on the fine lines around my mouth. I use the Sunburst C+ Superfruit Serum, and then I finish with Relevant’s One & Done Everyday Cream With SPF 40. It doesn’t leave a cast on the skin, and you can reapply it over makeup. In the shower, I use Saltair’s Exotic Pulp body wash and República’s Sugar Body Polish. I was not into bar soaps for a while, but the beauty retailer I co-founded, Thirteen Lune, now carries Gently. I love Karité’s Hydrating Body Cream and Goop’s Afterglow Body Oil — my skin just drinks those up. I’ve been using Kiehl’s Creme de Corps since college.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Putin’s Drive to Rewrite History Snares a Retired Lithuanian Judge
description: A few years ago, Kornelija Maceviciene ruled against Soviet officers for a brutal crackdown on pro-independence protesters in her country in 1991. That has made her a target for a Russian court.
content: When the International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant last year for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, a Moscow court launched a surprise counterattack: It ordered the arrest of a 70-year-old retired judge in Lithuania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Hwaida Saad and Eric Schmitt
title: Islamic State Claims Responsibility for Deadly Bombings in Iran
description: The group, which has struck before in Iran, has a long history of division with the country.
content: The Islamic State claimed responsibility on Thursday for the bombing attack that killed 84 people in Kerman, Iran, a day before, during a memorial procession for Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani, according to a post on the extremist group’s official Telegram account.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: I have an ambivalent reaction to writers’ biographies — in the balancing act between artists and their art, I’ll take the art on its own in almost every instance. But I do appreciate learning about the people who made it, especially if they led interesting or unusual lives, and all the more so if those lives can illuminate aspects of the work. So it’s a safe bet that, having started last year by reading Willa Cather’s “My Ántonia,” I’ll spend some time at the beginning of this year with Benjamin Taylor’s new Cather biography, “Chasing Bright Medusas,” which Andrea Barrett’s review calls “a brief, clear introduction to Cather’s life and work.” That’s on our reading list this week; why not add it to yours?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Education Dept. Official Resigns Over Biden’s Policies on Israel and Gaza
description: Tariq Habash, who is Palestinian American, said the Biden administration “does not value all human life equally.”
content: A top adviser at the Education Department has resigned over President Biden’s handling of the Israel-Hamas war, the second official to do so as the administration faces divisions over U.S. support for Israel’s bombardment in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: What to Watch This Weekend: Catch Up on ‘The Curse’
description: The second-to-last episode of this cringe dramedy starring Emma Stone, Nathan Fielder and Benny Safdie arrives this weekend. There’s still time to watch before the season finale.
content: “The Curse,” a nightmare-tinted drama about aspiring HGTV hosts, starring Nathan Fielder, Emma Stone and Benny Safdie, is approaching its finale; the show’s ninth of 10 episodes arrives this weekend: Friday on Paramount+ and Sunday at 9 p.m., on Showtime. The show’s discomfort is so intense it becomes mythical, its white awkwardness so potent that those in its blast zone question reality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ro Khanna
title: Democrats Must Not Repeat the Mistakes of Globalization
description: The advent of A.I. doesn’t have to mean the death of labor.
content: Last September, tech’s biggest names trekked to Capitol Hill for a forum on artificial intelligence. In a meeting closed to journalists, executives briefed nearly two-thirds of the Senate on the future of A.I. A few respected labor and civic leaders were present, but the tech titans dominated the headlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Call That an Earthquake? By L.A. Standards, It Was a Nothing.
description: New York City felt a little early morning quake on Tuesday with a magnitude of 1.7.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll find out more about the earthquake that shook New York just a little bit. We’ll also unpack statistics showing that overall crime fell slightly in New York City last year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: What if Farmers Were Taxed on Water? In California, Some Are.
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 4, 2023.
content: “The pricing was really difficult, when the water used to be, you know, free.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezekiel Kweku
title: The Thin Blue Line That Divides America
description: The stark symbol wielded in the Capitol riot was always more complicated than it seemed.
content: Among the banners that Donald Trump’s supporters carried as they stormed the Capitol three years ago — 2016’s Make America Great Again flags and 2020’s Keep America Great flags, Confederate battle flags, Gadsden flags, Pine Tree flags, the Stars and Stripes — appeared a now-familiar variant of the American flag: white stars on a black field, with alternating black and white stripes, except for the stripe immediately beneath the union, which is blue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Friday Briefing: Islamic State Claims the Iran Bombing
description: Plus the seven keys to longevity.
content: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for a bombing attack that killed at least 84 people in Kerman, Iran, on Wednesday, according to a post on the extremist group’s official Telegram account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: The Messenger, Which Aimed to Transform Media, Faces Dire Financial Straits
description: The company, which debuted last year with big plans to disrupt journalism, generated only $3 million in revenue by the end of December.
content: Shortly before the media start-up The Messenger launched last year, its president said the company planned to generate more than $100 million of revenue in 2024. It will need a major turn in fortune to get there.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 4, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Jan. 4, 2024.
content: An article on Wednesday about the collision of two aircraft as they landed in Tokyo misstated the type of Japan Coast Guard plane that was involved in the collision. It was a de Havilland Canada DHC-8, not an MA722, which was the aircraft’s identification number.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: The Man Who Destroys $3,000 Handbags on the Internet
description: Under the handle Tanner Leatherstein, Volkan Yilmaz rips, burns and slices apart luxury goods to show how much he thinks they are really worth.
content: One video opens with a large white leather handbag covered in the signature LV logo of Louis Vuitton. Within milliseconds, a hand with a switchblade swoops in and slashes a huge gash in the side of the bag before tearing it apart at its seams. In another, the distinctive red sole of Christian Louboutin is loudly ripped from a black stiletto using a wrench; in still another, scissors snip through a $2,200 Prada clutch before a man sets fire to a piece of the leather and turns it to ash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
title: Experts See a Message in Chinese Balloons Flying Over Taiwan
description: Some analysts see the objects as a calculatedly ambiguous reminder to voters that Beijing is watching.
content: A surge in sightings of balloons from China flying over Taiwan has drawn the attention of the island’s military and struck some experts as a calculatedly ambiguous warning to voters weeks before its presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Willa Cather and Yehudi Menuhin: An Unlikely, Unwavering Friendship
description: These two titans of 20th-century literature and music formed a profound, yearslong relationship across generations and backgrounds.
content: Early in 1935, a blizzard blew through New York City. The storm was so fierce, it virtually emptied Central Park. But Willa Cather spent her morning there, sledding with the violin prodigy Yehudi Menuhin and his sisters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: In Tense Election Year, Public Officials Face Climate of Intimidation
description: Colorado and Maine, which blocked former President Donald J. Trump from the ballot, have grappled with the harassment of officials.
content: The caller had tipped off the authorities in Maine on Friday night: He told them that he had broken into the home of Shenna Bellows, the state’s top election official, a Democrat who one night earlier had disqualified former President Donald J. Trump from the primary ballot because of his actions during the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Reflections
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Word of the Day: nix
description: This word has appeared in 27 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Israelis Worry a Blow Against Hamas May Bring Blowback
description: Israelis welcomed news that a top Palestinian militant had been killed, but feared that it might impede the release of hostages and kindle a broader war.
content: A day after a blast killed a senior Hamas leader outside Beirut, Lebanon, many Israelis welcomed the assassination as an important step in the campaign to destroy the militant group, but worried it might carry costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Katz, Kevin Quealy and Ben Blatt
title: Week 18 N.F.L. Playoff Picture: Mapping the Paths That Remain for Each Team
description: Detailed tables and scenarios explain the remaining paths to the playoffs.
content: Detailed tables and scenarios explain the remaining paths to the playoffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis and Alissa Wilkinson
title: And the 2023 Oscar Nominees Should Be …
description: Academy voters will do what they want, but if our chief critics had their way, these are the films and performers that would be up for Oscars this year.
content: Academy voters will do what they want, but if our chief critics had their way, these are the films and performers that would be up for Oscars this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Molly Cook Escobar
title: The Jan. 6 Riot Inquiry So Far: Three Years, Hundreds of Prison Sentences
description: More than 1,200 people have now been arrested in connection with the attack on the Capitol, and more than 450 sentenced to periods of incarceration. The investigation is far from over.
content: More than 1,200 people have now been arrested in connection with the attack on the Capitol, and more than 450 sentenced to periods of incarceration. The investigation is far from over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joyce Cohen
title: A Single Dad Wanted a Manhattan Pad Fit for Two. Would His Budget Be Enough?
description: After selling the family home in Westchester, an environmental engineer looked to ‘start over’ in the city — with his 23-year-old son in tow. Here’s what he found.
content: After selling the family home in Westchester, an environmental engineer looked to ‘start over’ in the city — with his 23-year-old son in tow. Here’s what he found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noele Illien
title: 36 Hours in Zurich
description: Ride a fondue tram, explore art galleries in a converted brewery and toboggan down a mountain in Switzerland’s largest city.
content: Ride a fondue tram, explore art galleries in a converted brewery and toboggan down a mountain in Switzerland’s largest city.

title: Nevada Man Attacks His Judge
description: Court video from Clark County, Nev., shows Deobra Redden throwing himself at Judge Mary Kay Holthus during his sentencing on Wednesday.
content: Court video from Clark County, Nev., shows Deobra Redden throwing himself at Judge Mary Kay Holthus during his sentencing on Wednesday.

title: Tetris Loses to 13-Year-Old Boy
description: Willis Gibson became the first person to advance so far in the original Nintendo version of Tetris that the game froze.
content: Willis Gibson became the first person to advance so far in the original Nintendo version of Tetris that the game froze.
